solution: When is Bob able to get a ribbon where each part has color ii? There should be at least n−kn−k parts of color ii. So if the number of parts with color ii is less than n−kn−k, Bob cannot repaint the whole ribbon into color ii.

So, Alice has to paint the ribbon in such a way that for every color, there are at most n−k−1n−k−1 parts of that color. There are at least two ways to check if it is possible: for example, you can calculate the maximum possible length of the ribbon such that it contains no more than n−k−1n−k−1 parts of every color; or you can calculate the maximum number of parts among all colors if you try to color the ribbon as evenly as possible.
